Award.AwardTitle: RUI: A laboratory study of ultrasonic scattering attenuation by possible microstructures in Earth's inner core
Award.AbstractNarration:
Earth's inner core is elastically anisotropic, with seismic waves propagating parallel to the rotation axis about 3% faster than those parallel to the equatorial plane. The inner core also exhibits an attenuation anisotropy, with the faster waves having smaller amplitudes. There is now evidence that the pattern of both anisotropies is more complex, exhibiting depth dependence, hemispherical variations, and smaller scale regional variations. The isotropic seismic velocity may also exhibit regional variations. These puzzling seismic inferences are clues as to the structure and evolution of the solid iron alloy inner core. This grant will allow the PI to investigate the causes of inner core attenuation and its anisotropy, and thus help to better understand the most remote part of our planet. In particular, in laboratory studies the PI will use ultrasonic waves to probe metallic alloys with a variety of microstructures that have been suggested for the inner core, employing ratios of wavelengths to grain and sub-grain lengthscales that are relevant to the inner core. By comparison with seismic data, this will allow the PI to quantify the relative importance of scattering attenuation versus intrinsic attenuation (viscoelasticity). As an RUI grant, the project will involve diverse undergraduates in all aspects of the research, providing them with training and experience in doing science.

Most explanations for the elastic anisotropy rely on a lattice preferred orientation (texturing) of hexagonal close-packed iron crystals, the most likely stable phase of iron under inner core conditions. Explanations for the texturing fall broadly into two classes, that due to solidification and that due to deformation. Directional solidification of metallic alloys typically results in columnar grains formed by primary and secondary dendrites of the primary compositional phase, with the secondary phase along grain boundaries and between dendrites, i.e., intragranular. Such microstructure has been proposed for the inner core, and scattering off grain boundaries of elongated crystals has been suggested as a cause for the attenuation anisotropy. Solidification microstructure is not thermodynamically stable, however, and annealing can result in coarsening of secondary dendrites, while maintaining the primary dendrites and columnar crystals, or possibly, in recrystallization and polygonal grain growth. The latter typically occurs in deformed materials exposed to high temperature. The PI will examine the ultrasonic scattering attenuation of three possible microstructures likely in Earth's inner core: directional solidified columnar grains composed of primary and secondary dendrites; directionally solidified and then annealed grains; and polygonal grains that result from recrystallization due to deformation and annealing. He will use Pb-Sn because of its simple eutectic phase diagram, ease of use, and relatively small single crystal elastic anisotropy; and microstructures with relative wavelength/scatterer dimensions thought to be similar to those in the inner core. The PI will use the shape and decay of the ultrasonic coda to determine the quality factor Q, and will compare the ultrasonic waveforms with seismic data to infer regional microstructure in the inner core, which will give insight into the evolution of the inner core.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated ultrasonic attenuation, due to scattering, in metallic alloys of different microstructures, in an effort to understand the seismic attenuation in Earth's inner core.

Although the details of seismic attenuation in Earth's inner core remain uncertain and require further investigation, there is evidence that it is varies laterally and with depth. It is possible that attenuation in the inner core is intrinsic, that is, due to internal friction as a seismic wave passes through. In this view variations in attenuation are due to variations in material properties of the inner core, or to variations in external conditions such as temperature. However, lateral variations such as temperature, in particular, are difficult to sustain.

Acting in parallel with intrinsic attenuation is scattering attenuation. Scattering attenuation results from variations in acoustical impedance, the product of density and wavespeed. In the inner core the latter is the more likely variable, because of the elastic anisotropy of the iron crystals comprising the inner core. Scattering conserves energy, but because of reflections an initial pulse has its amplitude decreased as a coda follows.

In addition to the magnitude of the acoustical impedance contrast, the relative size of the scatterers, D, and the wavelength is important, with scattering being a maximum when kD is close to 1, where k is the wavenumber. The shape of the scatterers can also be important. This project examines the ultrasonic scattering due to different microstructures that may be present in the inner core. These include elongated, dendritic crystals that are typical of directionally solidified metallic alloys; such crystals but annealed, which tends to eliminate smaller scale features; and finer-grained, equiaxed crystals that might be more representative of a heavily deformed material.

The idea behind the project is to examine in the laboratory the ultrasonic scattering of these three different microstructures for a range of kD that is similar to what might be present in the inner core. By then comparing with what is observed seismically, we hope to be able to determine the microstructure of the inner core, which will help to determine the evolution of the inner core. The elastic anisotropy of single crystals of iron under inner core conditions remains uncertain, but it is plausible that it is a few percent, so we used a lead-rich tin alloy as an analog because lead has a similar level of elastic anisotropy, and is easy to work with in the laboratory.

After making samples with the various microstructures, we examined the ultrasonic waveforms to look for systematic variations in scattering for a range of wavelengths. As one might expect the waveforms are quite messy, so we characterize them by the quality factor, the best exponential fit to the reflecting pulse amplitudes. That part of the work is done, but in order to compare with the seismic results we need to do numerical waveform modeling, which is now under way with seismologist Vernon Cormier. The first step will be to compare the numerical results with our laboratory data, to give confidence in the numerical results. We can then extend the numerical experiments to a parameter regime that better represents that in the inner core, but is not possible to achieve in the laboratory, so that we can better predict the inner core microstructure. We have begun the numerical work this summer, so although we have not yet gotten as far as we would have liked during the tenure of this project, the work is continuing and we are optimistic we will have interesting results in the near future.
